ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Photodeformable polymer materials: towards light-driven spoke-type micromotor application

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Using a photodeformable polymer material, liquid-crystalline polymer incorporated with azobenzene moieties, a spoke-type micromotor is designed, which could convert light energy directly into mechanical work. It consists of four driving belts, whose mechanical model is established and the driving moment of the micromotor upon irradiation with UV light and without photoirradiation is calculated, respectively. According to the calculated driving moment, the UV light and the visible light are arranged to irradiate from parallel and opposite direction of the micromotor simultaneously, which convert the bending deflection of the photodeformable polymer material belts to continuous rotation of the micromotor. As light is a green energy source that can be controlled remotely, instantly and without the aid of electric wires, the photodeformable polymer material has great potential to be utilized in micro-actuator and other relative applications.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
In recent years, a kind of photodeformable polymer material, liquid-crystalline polymer incorporated with azobenzene moieties, has attracted considerable attention from the material research community due to their specific properties, which could bend upon the irradiation of UV light and revert to its initial flat state upon visible light [1]. Ikeda and Yu firstly reported the photoinduced bending effect of single-domain liquid-crystalline films containing azobenzene moieties. In their research, they found that the films would bend towards the irradiation direction of UV light (360 nm) and revert to the initial flat film completely upon irradiation of visible light (450 nm). The reason for this phenomenon is that the extinction coefficient of the azobenzene moieties at 360 nm is large (

Therefore, bending is induced towards the incident direction of the actinic light [2]. It can be seen that this kind of material can convert light energy directly into mechanical work (the photomechanical effect) and could be very efficient as a single-step energy conversion. Furthermore, these photodeformable materials would be widely applicable because they can be controlled remotely just by manipulating the irradiation conditions.

At present, electrostatic driving, thermal driving, electromagnetic driving, and so on [3–6] are used as actuation methods for most of the MEMS actuators, but the inconvenience of energy supply is a drawback for all of the actuation methods. With the development of miniaturized MEMS, energy supply increasingly restricted the development of the micro-actuator. Compared to other actuation methods, optical driving can successfully solve this bottleneck problem because it can be controlled remotely, instantly, precisely without the aid of batteries and electric wires. Furthermore, light energy is clean and safe. Therefore, the micro- actuator fabricated with photodeformable polymer material will play a tremendous role in the development of MEMS [7–17]. In 1995, Lehmann and Stuke reported a linear micromotor, which is driven by thermal expansion forces caused by selective laser beam heating of the micromotor’s structural parts [18]. In 2008, Ikeda et al. [19] from Tokyo Institute of Technology reported a photo-activated plastic crawler-type motor with photodeformable material, which can rotate continuously by irradiating UV light and visible light from different angles.

In this study, a kind of spoke-type micromotor is designed, which can convert light energy directly into mechanical rotation. The driving moment actuating micromotor rotating is calculated. Then, according to the driving moment, the irradiation method is arranged. Furthermore, the prototype of the micromotor is fabricated and these experimental results indicate that the mechanical structure of the micromotor is applicable.

Section1.Heading: Design of the mechanical structure of the spoke-type micromotor
Section1.Para:
The mechanical structure of spoke-type micromotor is shown in Fig. 3a, consisting of stator (1), driving belt (2), micro bearing (3), rotor (4) and eccentric column (5). The mechanical structure of stator of micromotor is shown in Fig. 3b, consisting of base (1), bearing (2), eccentric column base (3), micro bearing (4) and eccentric column (5). The mechanical structure of the rotor of the micromotor is shown in Fig. 3c, which consists of the coupling flange (1), upright column (2) and output axis (3). Four photodeformable polymer material belts are installed on the upright column and the bearing of the eccentric column of the stator. The rotor of the micromotor is installed on the bearing of the stator. By irradiating the belts with UV light and visible light, the belts will be bended and restored. Owing to the change of the length between the two ends of the belt, the resultant moment of the belt acting on the upright column of the rotor is generated, which motivates the stator to rotate on the bearing of stator and the micro bearing. Furthermore, the moment of the micromotor is outputted by the output axis. How to arrange the irradiation condition, the position of the four belts and how to control their deformation continuously and orderly are the keys to realize the continuous operation of the rotor and these are described in detail in the next section.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para:
In our experiment, the irradiation is arranged not only for UV light as the above description but also for visible light, which increases the driving force to restore the belts from thir bending state to flat state. And this is very advantageous to the micromotor for continuous rotation. To drive the micromotor by light, the UV light and visible light are required to irradiate from the parallel and opposite direction as shown in Fig. 7. The photodeformable material belts upon exposure to UV light will bend towards the direction of irradiation of the UV light, which will give rise to driving moment to the rotor that restricts their deformation. Meanwhile, the recovery deformation of the belts in the visible light areas will also generate driving moment. Therefore, their resultant moment will drive the rotor to rotate when the position of the belts is arranged suitably. The direction of rotation is determined by the direction of resultant moment and we assume it is clockwise. During the rotation of the micromotor, the belts irradiated by UV light will be restored from the bent state to the initial flat form when it enters into the area of visible light. At the same time, the restored belts will enter into the UV light again and the rotation brings the belt to be exposed to UV and visible light, which enable the micromotor to rotate continuously. (In Fig. 7, the bold lines indicating the deformable belts are irradiated by visible light and the fine lines are irradiated by UV light. Besides, the dash lines indicate that it is as a marker belt.) Moreover, reverse rotation of this micromotor could also be induced just by changing the irradiation direction of the UV light and visible light.

Section1.Heading: Discussions and conclusions
Section1.Para:
In summary, the photodeformable polymer material, liquid-crystalline containing azobenzene moieties is successfully applied in this kind of spoke-type micromotor, which converts light energy to mechanical rotation in a single step. This light-driven micromotor is a new type of Micro Opto Mechanical Systems (MOMS) has some of the following characteristics that the MEMS do not have:
1.
The material used as the driven component of the micromotor is a polymer, which is easy to be processed into different shapes to meet the requirement of the driven unit of different actuators.
2.
Light energy is clean and safe and can be controlled remotely, instantly and precisely.
3.
The micromotor can rotate continuously without the aid of batteries, electrical wires or gears.
Consequently, we believe that it has a great potential to be used in cluster micro-robot and other relative applications, especially where efficient power supply to a mechanical system is battery-free and noncontact. With the development of material science and MEMS technology, light-driven micromotor could be used in bio-medical and military.
The structure of the micromotor is new and applicable; furthermore, the design, experiment and the analytical method of the micromotor could be referenced by other type motors.

The size of the prototype is in the range of millimeters for the present fabrication conditions in the laboratory. However, applications even on micrometer scale are possible through photolithography.
